Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: American Innovations in an Age of Discovery: Teaching Science and Engineering through 3D-printed Historical Reconstructions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced manufacturing technologies, such as 3D printing, are transforming design and several fields of engineering. This innovative project will use 3D technology to help students learn about science and engineering through the history of inventions in the United States. As part of science and engineering classes, middle and high-school students will use 3D printing technology to recreate historically significant inventions, using digitized versions from the Smithsonian Institution (e.g., the Wright brothers' airplane - http://3d.si.edu). The project will create modules that will connect these significant inventions from the past with contemporary technologies, science, and engineering. Student teamwork will help participants understand the collaborative process of invention. The project will develop supporting materials for middle school science and engineering teachers. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

The module development will address calls in recent national reports and standards for the integration of engineering in science teaching and learning. The research questions and data collection/analysis will examine how the modules impact student knowledge of the concepts and if teachers can successfully implement them in classrooms. Data to be collected include students' work on the modules, interviews and focus groups with students, interviews with teachers, and classroom observation. Using comparison classrooms, the study will also use pre-tests and post-tests of students' content knowledge to understand the impact of the modules in the treatment classrooms on students' knowledge of science and engineering. The goal will be to document the impact of the modules on students' learning in science and engineering courses and to understand how historical inventions can be used to engage students in how scientific and engineering innovation happen. The implementation will include school districts with diverse populations of students in two states, providing a range of test sites for the materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This three-year project involved the development of instructional materials and methods for teaching science and engineering to middle and high school students and the general public.  Our methods involve the re-creation of historic inventions such as the circa-1854 electromagnetic solenoid motor of Charles Grafton Page using modern manufacturing tools including 3D printers.  Other 'invention kits' developed include a Telephone Invention Kit based on the late 19th-century research, patents, and devices of Alexander Graham Bell and Werner Von Siemens.  Here students were able to create working voice-coil loudspeakers using relatively inexpensive cardstock die cutting machines.  

This project is the scientific and engineering component of a broader collaboration with education researchers at the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia and curators and educators at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History.  Collectively, the collaboration has produced prototype 'invention kits' and piloted them at several schools in engineering classes in the Charlottesville Virginia area.  The 'invention kits' provide the building blocks for allowing students to create their own engineering inventions.  For example, one middle school group extended the Solenoid Motor Invention Kit into a solenoid-motor powered mobile car by adding wheels, axles, and a body, all printed on a 3D printer.  Another group used the solenoid motor to activate a pop-up card of their own design. These examples were showcased by students at a day-long session at the Smithsonian National Museum of American History in Washington in their Sparks Lab.  

The PI for this project is a Professor of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Princeton University who has been teaching a history of engineering laboratory course for the general education of Princeton University students.  The introductory college-level course served as the organizational model for integrating science, history, and engineering design.  The collaboration between the PI, a technical specialist in science and engineering, and education faculty and graduate students at the University of Virginia, and museum educators and staff at the National Museum has been fruitful and is ongoing.

Two publications have resulted from this work as well as presentations at technical education conferences and workshops for teacher educators and teachers.
